info.game_comments:
1987 Teen Tournament quarterfinal game 1.
Inaugural Teen Tournament game.

(1, 1).clue: The bat parrot probably got its name from sleeping in this position

(2, 1).clue: Defacing books or shouting or throwing spitballs at the other readers
(2, 1).correct response: three activities prohibited in the library

(4, 1).clue: To compete with "G.I. Joe", Coleco has created a line of soldiers inspired by this Stallone film

(5, 1).clue: Hamilton, Ohio recently added this punctuation mark to its name, like our show's always had

(6, 1).clue: If you "boil the hides", it means your rear tires are producing this at the start of a drag race

(1, 2).clue: Too "lei"zy to migrate, the geese in this tropical state stay year-round

(2, 2).clue: On most reference books in your local library, you'll find this letter above the call number

(4, 2).clue: In 1977, Kenner sold gift certificates for toys based on this sci-fi film since the toys didn't exist yet

(5, 2).clue: "Hands Across America" raised money for the hungry & homeless in this country

(6, 2).clue: When fixing cars, "R & R" means remove & do this to an auto part

(1, 3).clue: A bird waterproofs its feathers with oil from its "preen gland", located at the base of this

(2, 3).clue: When a book has been checked out it's said to be "in" this

(4, 3).clue: Christmas stockings in 1986 were filled with this Hungarian inventor's "Magic", as well as Santa's

(5, 3).clue: In October 1986, Reagan & Gorbachev went face to face in this cold capital

(6, 3).clue: When your car is "on the hook", it's traveling this way

(2, 4).clue: In this classification system, WWII, 940.54, comes before the Civil War, 973.7

(4, 4).clue: Since 1949, this game manufacturer has sold about 1 million Candyland sets a year

(5, 4).clue: Father Lawrence Jenco, the Reverend Benjamin Weir, & David Jacobsen
(5, 4).correct response: hostages that were released from Beirut

(6, 4).clue: When a car has been "chopped", this part of it has been lowered

(2, 5).clue: Shirley Jones played this part by the book in "The Music Man"

(4, 5).clue: A battle of the bands is ensuing between Barbie & The Rockers & this doll & The Holograms

(5, 5).clue: In 1986, for the 1st time ever, 2 women ran against each other for gov. in this plains state

(1, 1).clue: Death of his son led him to write a "History of Spiritualism" before his last Sherlock Holmes book

(2, 1).clue: On the 1st day of spring or fall, the Sun is directly over this imaginary line

(3, 1).clue: This teenage Egyptian ruler gave birth to a son she claimed was Julius Caesar's

(4, 1).clue: Ben Franklin said, "There was never a good war or a bad" 1 of these

(5, 1).clue: Since 1941, Thanksgiving is observed on this Thursday in November

(6, 1).clue: Sacher Torte originated in this Austrian capital

(1, 2).clue: "A Christmas Carol" character who tells Scrooge, "I wear the chain I forged in life"

(2, 2).clue: Of about 10, 30, or 50%, percentage of Earth's surface covered by land

(3, 2).clue: Teen-aged Mary, Queen of Scots, also became queen of this country, because she'd married the Dauphin

(4, 2).clue: It was way back in 1696 that Mary Manley wrote there's "no time like" this

(5, 2).clue: "Shrove Tuesday", the day before Lent starts, is commonly called this in New Orleans

(6, 2).clue: Like lemon pie, "Baked Alaska" is covered with this, then put in an oven to brown

(1, 3).clue: Narrator of classic tales translated by Sir Richard Burton, or title of this "suite" music

(2, 3).clue: All of the peoples of the world belong to this single species

(3, 3).clue: At 15, she became the future Louis XVI's bride; at 18, she became queen

(4, 3).clue: Penguin's Modern Quotes lists "Supercalifragilistic- expialidocious" under his name

(5, 3).clue: Supposedly a union president suggested date of this holiday to fill gap between July 4th & Thanksgiving

(6, 3).clue: It's thought Saladin offered this fruity dessert, cousin to ice cream, to Richard I during Crusades

(2, 4).clue: Guinness says more people emigrate from this Latin country than any other in the world

(3, 4).clue: British monarch crowned in 1837, when she was barely 18

(4, 4).clue: 17th century English diarist known for the phrase "and so to bed"

(6, 4).clue: A dessert that might be appropriate while repairing shoes

(2, 5).clue: The term "second world" refers to this nation & its nearby allies

(3, 5).clue: Many claim that before Bloody Mary grabbed the throne, this "Lady" was Queen of England for 9 days

(0, 0).clue: Bordering on Mich. & N.Y., these 2 Great Lakes are the only ones to border on 1 state each
